results.title: The Pyre of Triune
results.brief_description:
A paint-on-glass animation exploring personal themes of spirituality - representing a journey into the soul and the discovery of the spirit of god, a struggle for meaning and the light within.
Created as part of coursework at the Centre for Animation and Interactive Media (AIM), RMIT, 1997.

results.title: Lost book found
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: The result of over five years of Super 8 and 16mm filming on New York City streets, ‘Lost Book Found’ melds documentary and narrative approaches into a complex meditation on city life. The piece revolves around a mysterious notebook filled with obsessive listings of places, objects, and incidents which serve as the key to a hidden city. It is a city on unconsidered geographies and layered artefacts - the relics of low-level capitalism and the debris of countless forgotten narratives. The project stems from the filmmaker’s first job in New York - working as a pushcart vendor on Canal Street. As usual, Cohen shot in hundreds of locations using unobtrusive equipment and generally without any crew. Influenced by the work of Walter Benjamin, Cohen created ‘an archive of undirected shots and sounds, then set out to explore the boundary’ between genres. During the process Cohen said, ‘I found connections between the street vendor, Benjamin’s ‘flaneur’ and my own work as an observer and collector of ephemeral street life’.

results.title: Spread your wings: making it with TAFE
results.creator_credit: Documentary Films, Technical and Further Education, Chris Stewart and John O'Shea
results.brief_description: An impressionistic film which is intended to provide information about the opportunities offered by Technical and Further Education in vocational training, and in recreational courses to meet community requirements. It is not intended to give detailed information on the breadth of courses and curricula but is rather a stimulus film aimed at encouraging enrolment.

results.title: Evaluation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changes…From the Inside”.
Depicts a school that takes its evaluation seriously. Keeping in touch with its community has required constant monitoring and some innovative adjustments. Staff, curriculum, in service and Supplementary Grants meetings are now one and the same and are occasions where parents and teachers learn together.

results.title: Indonesia: an Alternative Lifestyle
results.creator_credit: Experimental Film and Television Fund and Leigh Tilson
results.brief_description: A non-narrated film that contrasts behind-the-scenes life in both rural and urban Indonesia with the view of the country as seen by foreign tourists.

results.title: Scott no friends
results.brief_description:
This responsive display presents the moment, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

PM Scott Morrison got the cold shoulder at the G20 conference in Rome. His 11th-hour plan for net-zero emissions by 2050 was criticised at home and abroad for lacking any real details, except faith that uninvented tech might save the day, and the French president labelled him a liar over the submarine fiasco. Other world leaders made their displeasure to the government’s handling of recent issues known by collectively shunning the maskless Morrison during a group photo.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

results.description: PM Scott Morrison got the cold shoulder at the G20 conference in Rome. Not only did the French president label him a liar over the submarine fiasco, his 11th-hour plan for net-zero emissions by 2050 was criticised around the world (and at home) for lacking any new funding, policies or details, except faith that uninvented tech might save the day. Other world leaders made their displeasure known by collectively shunning the maskless Morrison during a group photo opportunity.

Other world leaders made their displeasure known by collectively shunning the maskless Morrison during a group photo opportunity.

results.title: In the Wake of the Stars
results.creator_credit: Cinesound, Bede Whiteman and Mark McDonald
results.brief_description: Aviation came quickly in Australia. In the early days reliable DC3’s carried everyone and everything. Then new faster and more comfortable aircraft were sought: the Fokker Friendship from Holland, the super Viscount from France and turbo jets from America. During training flights the attractions of gracious Amsterdam, gay Paris, England’s spring, New York’s people, Rome’s buildings and Australia’s scenic attractions are presented.

results.title: Community College Mt Gambier: growing
results.creator_credit: New Films, South Australian Film Corporation and Justin Milne
results.brief_description: This is the story of the South East Community College Mount Gambier. Features two teachers, Bev Puckridge and Ian Winter, who narrate throughout the film. Shows how students go back to their own communities and set up and teach smaller groups in woodwork, pottery, spinning etc. Emphasis is made that art is a natural part of our world - a natural thing to do. It is not the finished product that really matters, but the thought process used to achieve it.

results.title: In partnership with the people
results.creator_credit: Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production and John M. Bale
results.brief_description: Battery Point is one of the oldest parts of Hobart and the City Council is about to put into practice a development plan which will retain the character and charm of this area. Shows the signal station, the seamen’s cottages, the fine houses of the wealthy, Kelly’s Steps, St George’s Church and other historic items.

results.title: Dream
results.creator_credit: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill
results.brief_description: A partly animated film based on a series of drypoint prints (‘Movements’ and ‘Combats’) by Australian printmaker Charles Lloyd on the theme of aggression in society. The sound composition by Arthur Cantrill is a mix of percussion and altered piano (plucking and hitting strings and soundboard, played by Arthur Cantrill), sound effects (including breathing), and electronically modified children’s laughter, recorded on a Nagra reel to reel tape recorder and transferred to 16mm magnetic tracks which were laid and mixed in a professional sound studio, where reverberation was added to some sections.
